reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central pillar of the position: that large amounts of “software progress” (often framed as effective-compute gains) could sustain rapid algorithmic progress without more hardware, at least for several OOMs. If most gains were merely improved hardware utilization with a near ceiling, that would tighten compute bottlenecks and weaken the SIE case. However, the critique only addresses one important pathway (systems/utilization optimizations) and doesn’t engage much with other mechanisms emphasized/allowed by the position (e.g., shifting research methodology, extrapolation from smaller experiments, algorithmic/scaling-law changes, architecture changes, search/automation effects, multi-route ‘strongest link’ framing). It asserts specific utilization numbers (50–60%) and a <1 OOM bound without support, and overstates that post-saturation progress must be “purely sample efficiency.” Still, the basic point that utilization improvements have hard physical limits is correct and relevant. Clear and focused, with minimal fluff, but only moderately damaging given omissions and speculative quantitative claims.
title: Software efficiency gains are bounded by hardware utilization ceilings
